title: U.S. Takes Aim at Iran's Drone Program
summary: Iran's drones are seen as a more immediate danger than its nuclear program, Western security officials say. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration levied sanctions against several Iranian companies and their executives whom the U.S. has linked to Tehran's effort to develop armed drones for attacks on U.S. forces and allies.

title: Court Rules Against Religious Exemption for New York Healthcare Workers' Vaccine Mandate
summary: Christians who oppose abortion said they wouldn't get available Covid-19 vaccines because they were developed using fetal tissue. A federal appellate court sided with New York officials Friday and removed a temporary injunction that had allowed healthcare workers to seek religious exemptions to the state's Covid-19 vaccination mandate.

title: Supreme Court Denies Religious Exemption to State Vaccine Mandate for Healthcare Workers
summary: Doctor, others in Maine sought emergency order blocking requirement. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday denied an emergency request by healthcare workers in Maine for a religious exemption from the state's requirement that they be vaccinated against Covid-19.

title: Prince Andrew Asks New York Court to Dismiss Sex-Abuse Charges
summary: Virginia Giuffre's suit accuses Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell of coercing her to have sex with the royal in early 2000s. Prince Andrew asked a New York federal court to dismiss a sex-abuse lawsuit filed against him by a Jeffrey Epstein accuser, saying the woman has profited off baseless allegations for years and sullied his reputation.

title: GameStop's Chief Operating Officer Departs
summary: Former Amazon executive Jenna Owens has left the company after joining in March. GameStop Corp.'s chief operating officer, Jenna Owens, has left the company, less than a year after joining.

title: Cannabis Company Tilray Sets Blueprint for U.S. Expansion
summary: Tilray is one of several cannabis companies structuring U.S. acquisitions to stay within the bounds of their U.S. listings. Cannabis company Tilray Inc. is expanding across the U.S. to get a foothold in the market for legal marijuana, pursuing transactions and targets in related industries to stay within the bounds of its U.S. listing requirements.

title: Revisiting Climate at the Supreme Court
summary: The Justices agree to hear cases on the EPA's authority to regulate CO2 emissions.. The Supreme Court on Friday rudely interrupted President Biden's trip to the Glasgow climate confab by agreeing to hear cases that will let the Justices revisit their misguided Massachusetts v. EPA (2007) ruling that empowered the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate greenhouse gases.

title: Paperchain Uses DeFi to Speed Streaming Payments to Musicians
summary: The startup gets streaming data from music labels and distributors on their artists, then uses their invoices as collateral for DeFi loans to pay the musicians more quickly. Musicians who distribute their work on streaming platforms typically wait weeks to get paid for the traffic they generate. Paperchain Inc., a startup that just raised pre-seed money, says it has a way to get that down to a few days and produce a steady stream of income for musicians.

title: Apple, Tesla, Robinhood: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Apple Inc.

title: Judge Inclined to Have Burr's Brother-in-Law Testify in Insider-Trading Probe
summary: Lawyer for Gerald Fauth ask why the GOP senator hasn't been asked to testify. WASHINGTON-A federal judge on Friday said he was inclined to require Sen. Richard Burr's brother-in-law to testify in an investigation that examines whether the two men engaged in insider trading.

title: The Climate Summit to Nowhere
summary: From awful timing to unrealistic goals, COP26 has it all.. World leaders converge on Glasgow for a climate summit this weekend, and don't laugh. This may be the worst-timed summit in history, but the delegates can still do substantial damage to the global economy, though none of it will matter to the climate.

title: Abolishing Minneapolis P.D.
summary: If you're a criminal, you'll love Question 2 on Tuesday's ballot.. The "defund the police" movement began in Minneapolis in 2020 after the murder of George Floyd, and on Tuesday the city's voters will decide if they also want to end policing as we know it.

title: The Afghan Terror Threat
summary: Americans are still left behind, and ISIS is growing in strength.. Two months from his disastrous withdrawal, President Biden wants Americans to forget about Afghanistan and the Americans left behind. Too bad Islamic terrorists haven't lost interest in the U.S.

title: HGTV Stars Cortney and Robert Novogratz to Ask Nearly $18 Million for Spanish-Style Home in L.A.
summary: The well-known house-flippers are moving back to New York to concentrate on their next project, a bright pink townhouse. Interior designers Cortney and Robert Novogratz of HGTV home-flipping fame are putting their modern Spanish home in Los Angeles on the market for $17.995 million.

title: The Amendment That Remade America
summary: The First? The Second? No, the 14th-the basis for every claim against a state government for violating individual rights. Randy Barnett and Evan Bernick say it's time to assert its original meaning.. What's the most important amendment to the U.S. Constitution? The First, which guarantees the freedoms of religion, speech and assembly? If you favor gun rights, perhaps the Second? Criminal-defense lawyers might be inclined to invoke the Fifth. Randy Barnett and Evan Bernick make a case for an amendment that isn't even in the Bill of Rights-the 14th, ratified in 1868.

title: How to Fix Social Media
summary: Revelations about Facebook, Instagram and TikTok have highlighted the problems posed by the biggest social media sites. What would it take to reform the platforms and limit their harm?.

title: Pro Sports without Woke Politics
summary: Encouraging news from the NBA and Major League Baseball.. Lately it can seem almost impossible to watch a game without being subjected to political lectures. But two interesting developments in professional sports this week suggest that the average fan may finally expect relief.

title: 10 Letters to Read: October's Most Notable Letters to the Editor
summary: A selection of contributions from our readers, including a former U.S. president, a New Jersey tax refugee and everyone in between.. A selection of the month's most noteworthy letters, ordered chronologically.

title: Democrats Tackle Final Details of Biden's $1.85 Trillion Framework
summary: Some lawmakers hope to pass both infrastructure bill and separate social spending and climate legislation next week. WASHINGTON-Democrats turned to finalizing the details of President Biden's $1.85 trillion social-spending and climate framework, with some lawmakers pushing to add measures lowering prescription drug prices and repealing a cap on the state and local tax deduction.

summary: The National Academy of Sciences made an elementary error that could cost more than a million jobs. Here is a story that helps explain why people have lost trust in public-policy experts:

title: Supreme Court to Consider EPA's Authority to Limit Carbon Emissions From Power Plants
summary: Coal companies, some states challenge lower-court ruling that gave Environmental Protection Agency broad latitude to regulate. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to consider the scope of the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to restrict greenhouse-gas emissions from power plants, taking on a case that could have a significant impact on future regulations from the Biden administration.

title: Wuhan Lab Workers Likely Unaware of Covid-19 Before Pandemic, Spy Agencies Say
summary: Declassified intelligence report says lab workers were likely unaware of new coronavirus before the pandemic. WASHINGTON-Researchers at a Wuhan, China, laboratory were probably unaware of the existence of the virus that causes Covid-19 before the pandemic began in late 2019, and if it leaked from the lab, it was likely the result of an accident not connected to deliberate genetic engineering, a U.S. intelligence report released on Friday said.

title: Study of Hospitalized Covid-19 Patients Shows Vaccination Is Better Guard Than Prior Infection
summary: CDC research adds to body of knowledge demonstrating strength of vaccines against contracting the disease. Covid-19 was over five times more common among hospitalized people who were unvaccinated and had a previous infection, compared with those who were fully vaccinated and hadn't had Covid-19 before, a study published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found.

title: The Views That Made Me Persona Non Grata at MIT
summary: I believe academic hiring should be based on merit and that hurt feelings are no reason to ban opinions.. I am a professor at the University of Chicago. I was recently invited to give an honorary lecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The lecture was canceled because I have openly advocated moral and philosophical views that are unpopular on university campuses.

title: Big Tech, Big Oil-Every Industry Is Big Tobacco Now
summary: At least U.S. intelligence agencies offer a rare voice of realism about the climate blame game.. It's worth remembering why tobacco executives lied in the infamous 1994 congressional hearings. Not to fool customers into continuing to smoke. Americans by then knew for decades that smoking was deadly. Polls in 1994 showed smokers actually overestimated the damage smoking was likely doing to them.

title: FDA Authorizes Pfizer Vaccine for Young Children
summary: The inoculation is the first cleared in the U.S. for children as young as 5 years old. The Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE was authorized for use in children as young as 5 years old, the first shot that federal health regulators have permitted for them in the U.S.

title: Meeting Macron, Biden Calls Handling of Australia Submarine Deal 'Clumsy'
summary: French and U.S. leaders seek to overcome tensions on eve of G-20 summit after security pact sparked diplomatic ructions. ROME-President Biden said his administration was "clumsy" in handling negotiations on a submarine contract with Australia that led to a diplomatic rupture with France, as he met French President Emmanuel Macron in an attempt to mend relations with the longtime U.S. ally.

title: Andrew Cuomo's Criminal Summons Released Faster Than Expected, Sheriff Says
summary: Albany County sheriff says he had hoped to confer with district attorney before charges against New York's former governor were made public. The Albany County sheriff said Friday that he was surprised a criminal summons charging former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo with forcible touching was issued so quickly, but said it shouldn't affect the case moving forward.

title: Stocks Shrug Off Downbeat Apple, Amazon Earnings
summary: Bull market's resilience was on display Friday as stocks capped their strongest month since November despite woes at two of the world's biggest companies. U.S. stocks capped their strongest month since November by shrugging off woes at two of the biggest companies in the stock market, Apple and Amazon.com .

title: How a Master Made the Page Leap to Life
summary: 'Portrait of an Older Man' is the only drawing that can be securely ascribed to Jan van Eyck.. In 1435, The influential Italian theorist and architect Leon Battista Alberti extolled painting for its ability "to represent the dead to the living many centuries later, so that they are recognized by viewers with pleasure and deep admiration for the artist." Schooled in ancient literature, he cites a number of Greek artists to make his point. But the artist who seemed to contemporaries to surpass those exemplary figures was Jan van Eyck (before 1390-1441), whose work was as highly prized in Italy as in the Netherlands where he lived and worked. Visitors to "Van Eyck to Mondrian: 300 Years of Collecting in Dresden" at New York's Morgan Library & Museum (through Jan. 23, 2022) have an exceptional chance to see why.

title: Facebook Joins a Crowded Field in the Race to Build the 'Metaverse.' We All Have a Stake in the Outcome.
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's new plan for Facebook is one of several competing visions for an immersive digital reality. Tech billionaires are a quirky lot. Some are attempting to build a world imagined in utopian visions of the future, such as 'Star Trek.' Others, like Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg, would like us to spend as much time as possible here on earth, in what they call a "metaverse." Facebook, which renamed itself Meta Platforms on Thursday-just "Meta" for short-is truly all-in on the concept. It's as if Goldman Sachs were to rename itself Crypto.

title: Haiti's Powerful Gangs Hold Country Hostage Over Fuel
summary: Resume Subscription. Haitian gangs have kidnapped more and more people in recent months, including a group of 17 American and Canadian missionaries and their families currently being held for ransom. But now a powerful gang is trying something new: Holding the entire country hostage.

title: Microsoft Overtakes Apple as Most Valuable Company
summary: The last time Microsoft had a bigger market cap than Apple was July 2020. Microsoft Corp. is once again the most valuable company in the U.S., with the software heavyweight's market cap hitting $2.49 trillion and surpassing Apple Inc . for the first time in more than a year.

title: Milton Avery Made Art by Subtracting From Nature
summary: In his influential paintings, the American artist turned people and landscapes into abstract forms.. Milton Avery sometimes boasted, not quite tongue-in-cheek, that he could make a tube of paint last longer than any other artist. His signature technique involved thinning the pigment to near-translucence, then applying it layer over layer to create a luminous, glaze-like finish. In the resulting works-as his friend, the painter Mark Rothko, put it-"poetry penetrated every pore of the canvas to the very last touch of the brush."

title: Zendesk Needs to Prove It's Not Bananas
summary: Acquisition of SurveyMonkey parent gets a big thumbs down as details delayed to analyst meeting. Zendesk investors already weren't the calmest bunch. A surprise acquisition seems to have pushed them over the edge.

title: California Port Congestion Fees Divide Importers, Operators
summary: Retailers say the levies on containers stuck at terminals will end up hitting powerless freight customers. A new measure intended to relieve congestion at Southern California ports threatens to pit U.S. importers against ocean carriers, highlighting divisions and competing interests at America's busiest gateway for container imports.

title: Zendesk, Momentive Shares Fall on Merger Plan
summary: Deal would roll SurveyMonkey parent company into Zendesk's customer-service platform. Investors sold off shares of Zendesk Inc. and Momentive Global Inc. on Friday, signaling skepticism of the customer-service platform's plan to buy the SurveyMonkey parent company for about $4.13 billion in stock.

title: Parts of East Coast Could See Flooding This Weekend
summary: National Weather Service warns some areas could see biggest tidal flood events in past 10 to 20 years. A large storm moving into the East Coast is expected to bring strong winds, tidal flooding and severe thunderstorms beginning Friday and into the weekend.

title: China Adds Wiggle Room on Climate Change
summary: Beijing's action plan contains reference to building new coal-fired power plants, a late revision. China's blueprints for reducing greenhouse-gas emissions, landing ahead of two global summits in Europe, have disappointed climate advocates who had hoped for an ambitious road map from Beijing.

title: Graveyard Shift (Saturday Crossword, October 30)
Hall of Mirrors (Saturday Puzzle, October 30)
FAA Plans Warnings to Pilots, Airlines Over New 5G Rollout
summary: Air-safety regulators tussle with telecom regulators over safety concerns ahead of expansion of new wireless technology planned in December. U.S. air-safety regulators are preparing to issue warnings to pilots and airlines about potential interference with key cockpit safety systems by a new 5G wireless service slated to go live as soon as early December, according to current and former government and aviation industry officials briefed on the matter.

title: The Ex-Banker Who Wants Banks to Pay for Climate Change
summary: Resume Subscription. Diplomats heading to the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow next week know their governments can only raise a fraction of the trillions needed to cut carbon emissions and transition the energy market to renewables. They asked Mark Carney to come up with the rest.

title: Readers to President Trump: Knock It Off
summary: His claims of election fraud aren't true and undermine our democracy.. Regarding "President Trump Responds on Pennsylvania" (Letters, Oct. 28): In 2020, former President Trump lost Wisconsin, Arizona, Georgia, Michigan and Pennsylvania-all states he won in 2016. To have won in 2020, Mr. Trump needed three of those states including Pennsylvania or four of them without Pennsylvania. Adding Pennsylvania alone wouldn't have changed the result.

title: Rapper Fetty Wap Charged With Drug Trafficking
summary: Performer arrested at Citi Field Ballpark where he had been scheduled to appear at a concert. Rapper Fetty Wap was charged in what prosecutors allege was a multimillion-dollar bicoastal drug-trafficking operation that involved transporting cocaine, heroin and other opioids across the U.S. in hidden compartments in cars, according to an indictment unsealed Friday in federal court in New York.

title: We Need to Struggle to Be Fulfilled
summary: What we can't handle is feeling unnecessary.. In "Why We Choose to Suffer" (Review, Oct. 16), Paul Bloom makes a good case that we humans need a reasonable dose of adversity in our lives. Sebastian Junger, in his excellent book "Tribe," says that we can handle hardship. What we can't handle is feeling unnecessary, and modern society does a good job of making people feel they aren't really needed.

title: The Left, the Jews and the Hard Currency of Grievance
summary: Despite ample persecution in the past, the Jewish people thrive.. Regarding Elliot Kaufman's op-ed about the Sunrise Movement's anti-Zionism ("Will the Sun Ever Set on Anti-Semitism?" Oct. 23): Left-wing groups trade in historical grievance and victimhood. Given that the Jews have been hounded in the West for, let's say, the past 1,000 years, and driven to the brink of annihilation in Europe in the past 100 years, it is notable that they continue to thrive and contribute great things to America and elsewhere. Israel, the only democracy in a very tough neighborhood, shares most Americans' values regarding liberty and human rights, including the rights of Israeli Arabs.

title: Noonan Asks the Wrong Question About Colin Powell
summary: Is America still producing the ignorant and bigoted people who tried to stop the late general?. Regarding Peggy Noonan's column "Colin Powell's Great American Journey" (Declarations, Oct. 23): The question, included at the end of her column, should not be whether we are still producing people like Colin Powell. There has always been and will continue to be Colin Powells, and better, coming from the black American community. How many centuries of evidence-people of high character and capabilities-do black Americans have to present? The question should be: Is America still producing the ignorant and bigoted people who tried to stop Powell from contributing his talents to the greater American good? Therein lies the challenge of establishing true harmony across the American landscape.

title: What 'The Lehman Trilogy' Misses
summary: The transition from Robert Lehman to Richard Fuld brought a change in culture.. The play "The Lehman Trilogy," reviewed by Terry Teachout (Arts in Review, Oct. 15), sadly gives short shrift to the contrast between Lehman Brothers under the leadership of Robert Lehman and that of Richard Fuld. My father, Morris Gardner, saw that during the 50 years he worked at the storied firm, retiring as comptroller.

title: 10 Haunted House Ideas to Make Your Home Extra Spooky This Halloween
summary: One-up your neighbors' yard displays with these pro ideas-from customizable headstones to computer-animated eyes. Plus a jack o'lantern that outshines them all.. HALLOWEEN IS serious business in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., and adjacent Tarrytown. But nobody there embraces the area's holiday heritage with more fervor than Arthur Klock. "Some people go pretty hard on their houses," said Mr. Klock, "but not to the extent that I do. I'm definitely the crazy person in town."

title: Wine and Waterfalls-Welcome Back to Canada's Niagara Peninsula
summary: Resume Subscription. ROUGHLY SPEAKING, there are two kinds of wine regions in the world. The most common is modeled after the French, where châteaux are approached with reverence, wines swirled with knowing anticipation and notes of cherry and leather proclaimed by experts. The wineries may be lovely, but the experience is more about how fantastic the wine is. Canada's Niagara Peninsula-set between Lake Ontario and Lake Erie-follows the rarer path. It's more about the good times you have with the wine than the wine itself.

title: Inside the Alec Baldwin Shooting: A Dysfunctional Set and a Fatal Mistake
summary: Resume Subscription. SANTA FE, N.M.-Alec Baldwin drew the black revolver from his holster as he sat in the pew of an Old West church, dressed as an aging cowboy from the late 1800s.

title: Prominent Trump Critic Adam Kinzinger Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: GOP lawmaker, one of two Republicans on panel probing Jan. 6 riot, recently had his district redrawn. WASHINGTON-Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R., Ill.), one of 10 GOP lawmakers who voted to impeach then President Donald Trump on a charge of inciting an insurrection at the Capitol, said on Friday that he wouldn't run for re-election next year.

title: U.S. Prices, Wages Rise at Fastest Pace in Decades
summary: Strong consumer demand and supply shortages test economy with rapid uptick in inflation. Consumer prices rose at the fastest pace in 30 years in September while workers saw their biggest compensation boosts in at least 20 years, according to new government data released Friday.

title: WHO Chief Tedros Unopposed in Bid for Second Term
summary: The leader of the global health organization has been criticized by both the U.S. and China, but is backed by many developing countries and European governments. World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, who has presided during one of the biggest public-health crises in decades, appeared likely to lead the organization for a second five-year term, after a deadline for countries to nominate other candidates passed without any government presenting a challenger.

title: Marc Andreessen Is the Buyer of Serge Azria's Malibu Home
summary: The fashion mogul's compound sold for $177 million, setting a California record. Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen and his wife, Laura Arrillaga-Andreessen, are the buyers of a Malibu compound that sold for $177 million, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: In the Civil War Graveyard, Every Headstone Tells a Story
summary: The ghost tales we heard in a local cemetery had nothing on the real lives of the people buried there.. Princeton, Ind.

title: Meta Shares Surge. No, Not Facebook's Meta.
summary: Canadian company's stock jumps; it has similar name as the rebranded Facebook but no relation. A Canadian company's stock surged recently. Investors apparently confused it for the rebranded Facebook .

title: Facebook Changes Name to Meta: What to Know
summary: Tech giant to rebrand as CEO Mark Zuckerberg looks to reposition the company around the metaverse. The decision by Facebook Inc. to change its name to Meta reflects the company's perceived growth opportunities beyond its namesake social-media platform.

title: Chinese Video Platform Kuaishou Says CEO Steps Down
summary: Co-founder Su Hua's move follows similar actions by the CEOs of other Chinese tech giants amid a regulatory crackdown. Kuaishou Technology , which owns a popular short-video platform in China, said chief executive and co-founder Su Hua has stepped back from day-to-day business, joining several peers at other Chinese tech giants who have made similar moves amid a regulatory crackdown.

title: Volvo Shares Soar in Trading Debut, but Fall Short of Ambitious Target
summary: Swedish car maker's IPO offers window into divide between old-guard auto companies and Tesla. BERLIN-Shares in Volvo Cars AB rose sharply higher in their debut Friday, closing the day 23% above their offering price but below the top of the Swedish car maker's initial target range for the closely watched offering.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: A look at the not-so-mad George III, David Copperfield's history of magic, George Orwell the gardener, a new tale in the world of 'Wicked' and more..

title: Exxon Mobil's Strategy: Be a Lean, Mean Cash Machine
summary: Oil companies are trimming capital expenditures while boosting shareholder returns. That could come back to bite.. Crude oil and natural gas prices are at multiyear highs, but oil-major executives can't exactly rest easy these days-especially not those at Exxon Mobil.

title: Biden Administration Tries Again to End Trump-Era Remain-in-Mexico Immigration Policy
summary: Officials to ask court to reconsider ruling that ordered a restart of the border program. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is making a second attempt to end the Remain-in-Mexico program in the face of a court ruling ordering the government to restart the Trump-era border policy.

title: Biden Says Pope Told Him He Is a Good Catholic
summary: President, who supports abortion rights, says Pope Francis told him to continue receiving Communion. VATICAN CITY-President Biden, after meeting Pope Francis, said the pontiff told him to continue receiving Communion, amid a controversy among U.S. church leaders over whether the president's support for abortion rights should disqualify him from receiving the sacrament.

title: 'The Last King of America' Review: The Method and the Madness
summary: Seeing George III as a monarch of moderation.. 'It takes many good deeds to build a good reputation," Benjamin Franklin said, "and only one bad one to lose it." His aphorism, one might say, had royal support. George III (1738-1820) enjoyed one of the longest reigns in British history, but he is known mostly for his turbulent early years as king and the loss of Britain's American colonies. Thomas Paine called him "a wicked tyrannical brute"; Thomas Jefferson, in the Declaration of Independence, said his character was "marked by every act which may define a tyrant." As if such charges weren't enough, George III suffered in his later years from bouts of mental illness that eventually curtailed his reign.

title: 'David Copperfield's History of Magic' Review: Treasury of Illusions
summary: From the 16th century to the 21st, a backstage tour of stage magic from one of its most successful showmen.. 'Magic matters," says David Copperfield. "It transports people into a world in which the impossible appears possible." It was magic, after all, that transported him-David Seth Kotkin, born 65 years ago in Metuchen, N.J.-from the middle-class home of a haberdasher into a wildly successful year-round residency at the Las Vegas MGM Grand. No, he didn't sell his soul to the devil to achieve his renown. He simply gave all of his time and talent, from the age of 8, to the art and craft of illusion-the recondite stage world of card tricks and sleight of hand, jaw-dropping escapes and levitating ladies-of which he is perhaps today's most famous and highly paid practitioner.

title: Hilary Swank Lists Los Angeles Home for $10.5 Million
summary: The Netflix 'Away' star is selling her Pacific Palisades compound with a movie theater after moving to Colorado during Covid. Not long after buying a house in Los Angeles in 2007, the actress Hilary Swank added a 16-seat movie theater, lounge and concession stand. Her goal, she said, was to watch movies "correctly, the way they are meant to be seen." That included snacks: The concession stand has an antique popcorn machine, candy and beer.

title: Hilary's Hacienda
summary: The Los Angeles home of actress Hilary Swank is a hacienda-style house built in the 1920s.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: MacBook Pro 2021 Review: Nearly Perfect Back-to-the-Future Laptops
summary: Full-size ports, real function keys and other retro features, plus cutting-edge M1 Pro and M1 Max chips, make the new MacBook Pro models the laptops to beat. "Study the past if you would define the future."

title: New Policy Gives FTC Greater Control Over How Companies Do Mergers
summary: Democratic commissioners to seek merger-veto rights on some future transactions, prompting GOP dissent. WASHINGTON-The Federal Trade Commission, led by new Democratic Chairwoman Lina Khan, has adopted a series of policy changes aimed at cracking down on corporate mergers, sparking deep partisan disagreement at the agency.

title: Republicans Target Pro-Union Electric-Vehicle Provision in Biden Spending Plan
summary: GOP senators will likely ask parliamentarian to rule against subsidy available only for union-built cars. WASHINGTON-Republicans are expected to ask the Senate parliamentarian to strip from Democrats' social spending and climate legislation a provision giving special tax incentives for the purchase of electric vehicles made with union labor.

title: 'Head of the Class' Review: The New Curriculum
summary: This reboot has a new crop of students and a lot of partying.. Those of durable memory will remember a television series titled "Head of the Class," about a special group of students at the fictional Millard Fillmore High School in Manhattan-you can see the jokiness in its bones right there. Millard Fillmore, 13th president of the United States, was a proud member of the Know Nothing Party. "Head of the Class" achieved so well it remained on air from 1986 to 1991. Now, on Thursday, HBO Max will be releasing its new "Head of the Class." And from the looks of the first three episodes of this 10-part series, the 21st-century version will bear scant resemblance to the original.

title: Shiba Inu Can Bite Its Owners
summary: Dog breed behind Dogecoin and copycats holds clues for what could happen to cryptocurrencies. Much popular. Such irrational.

title: Why Won't Employees Use Their Companies' Mental-Health Benefits?
summary: As businesses expand their benefits, they are looking for new ways to overcome workers' resistance. Many companies are expanding their mental-health benefits, but getting employees to take advantage of them can be challenging. Puget Sound Energy is on a mission to change that.

title: 'The Young H.G. Wells' Review: The Original Futurist
summary: Wells rarely focused on perfecting his books, moving on quickly to new subjects to feed his restless imagination.. Does anyone read H.G. Wells anymore? The question has been asked periodically since his death in 1946, and the answer is invariably a qualified yes. Of Wells's more than 100 books, his best known remain his groundbreaking early science fiction, including "The Time Machine" (1895) and "The War of the Worlds" (1898), which paved the way for generations of fantasies about time travel, future dystopias, and alien attacks. The majority of Wells's prescient social, scientific and political commentary and his scores of issue-driven novels are no longer widely read, yet the prolific author who was called "the man who invented tomorrow" remains a household name.

title: Politics: When the Lights Go Down in the City
summary: Four books on the mismatch between progressive ideals and their impact on the American city.. Progressive city officials in the 2020s appear determined to make all the mistakes liberal city officials made in the 1970s and '80s, but with updated language. Michael Shellenberger's "San Fransicko: Why Progressives Ruin Cities" chronicles various experiments in unreality conducted by one city's activists and political class in the 21st century. It is a bracing narrative.

title: 'Orwell's Roses' Review: The Nature of Truth
summary: For Orwell, experience of the small-scale natural world was an inoculation against ideological brainwashing and destructive modernity.. "Orwell's Roses" opens with a series of journeys. The first takes Rebecca Solnit by jetliner from the American West Coast to London. The second conveys her by train from King's Cross to the town of Baldock in rural Hertfordshire. The third rattles her by taxi to a small village named Wallington, lost amid the rolling East Anglian farmland. Her aim is to visit the tiny cottage once known as "the Stores," which George Orwell rented between 1936 and 1948, where he briefly "played at being a shopkeeper" (as a skeptical friend put it) and in the garden of which he grew the roses that feature in a 1946 essay, "A Good Word for the Vicar of Bray."

title: Fiction: Tom McCarthy's 'The Making of Incarnation'
summary: In a novel from the author of 'Remainder,' a group of engineers seek transcendence via technology.. In his 2012 manifesto "Transmission and the Individual Remix," modestly subtitled "How Literature Works," Tom McCarthy set out his idea that writers have functioned like computers since before computers existed, not creating so much as broadcasting "a set of signals" that are continuously rearranged and repeated in a vast feedback loop of language. His new novel, "The Making of Incarnation," stretches this concept beyond art to encompass all aspects of experience, which "make up an integrated circuit, in which servo-mechanism isn't just the mode of mankind, but his measure also. And not just of mankind: elevators, steamboat engines, jellyfish amalgams, the whole architecture of abstracted systems such as economics or the law-these, too, are birthed and structured by (and therefore legible within) the matrix-womb of cybernetics." For the novel's engineers, as for Mr. McCarthy, the coming technological singularity is not a nightmare but a consummation.

title: 'Unearthing the Secret Garden' Review: Seeds of a Classic
summary: Frances Hodgson Burnett came to gardening late-but the passion flowered in both her fiction and the real world.. In temperate climes, autumn is the season for putting gardens to bed. Gardeners tidy away dried leaves and stems, mulch flowerbeds, and tuck tender bulbs of hyacinth, daffodil and tulip under the soil for a long winter's sleep. Gone are the blossoms and bees, the colors and fragrance. Melancholy would seem to be in order. So it's delightful to learn that Frances Hodgson Burnett (1849-1924), prolific writer and joyful exponent of horticultural magic, did not mind the leafless trees and drab turf of the chilly months. She didn't welcome the cold, but she loved poring over seed catalogs, plotting new arrangements of plants and anticipating the coming glory of spring. In the flowering expanses that Burnett cultivated in England, and later in America and Bermuda, she rejoiced in the cycle of the seasons.

title: Mysteries: Laughter in the Dark
summary: An aging detective, an aging estate and an aging murderess figure in a trio of decidedly sprightly mysteries.. In "Diamond and the Eye," the latest entry in Peter Lovesey's procedural series set in Bath, England, Chief Investigating Officer Peter Diamond gets drawn into one of the toughest cases of his career. He does so at the behest of Johnny Getz, an aggressively hard-boiled, Yank-talking private detective whom Diamond tabs a "Bogart impersonator . . . as English as a cricket bat."

title: New York State to Sell Unilever Shares After Ben & Jerry's Israel Decision
summary: Pension fund says ice-cream brand's parent company broke its policy that prohibits the boycott of Israel. New York's state pension fund said it would sell its shares in Ben & Jerry's owner Unilever PLC following a review of the ice-cream brand's decision to stop retailing its products in Jewish settlements located in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: 'Karachi Vice' Review: The City as a Jigsaw Puzzle
summary: The Pakistani metropolis, once a haven for refugees, is deeply and violently split along ethnic lines.. Residents of any American metropolis who think that they live in civic hell because of homeless men on the subway, gangland rat-a-tat in the inner city and shoplifters at Walmart should steal a glance at Karachi for a jolt of harsh perspective. Would they prefer life in this Pakistani conurbation of 20 million people served by 30,000 underpaid (and often easily bribed) cops, a city racked by ethnic violence, political turf wars (fought with AK-47s), territorial battles between crime dons (also fought with AK-47s), and widespread Islamist extremism (expressed in periodic and pitiless public bombings)?

title: Deflating Your Inflation Fears
summary: Rising prices eat away at the purchasing power of your assets. But taking on more risk to fight inflation can do more harm than good.. Inflation.

title: Fantasy: Gregory Maguire's 'The Brides of Maracoor'
summary: The author of 'Wicked' continues the story of Rain, granddaughter of the Wicked Witch of the West.. Gregory Maguire's spin on "The Wizard of Oz," which came out in 1995 as "Wicked," was reworked as the long-running Broadway musical of the same name and followed by three further novels. The last of the sequels was 2011's "Out of Oz," which centered on the Wicked Witch's granddaughter Rain. In "The Brides of Maracoor," Mr. Maguire has picked up the story again-but in a quite different location.

title: Five Best: Books on the Domestic Lives of Men and Women
summary: Selected by Hilma Wolitzer, the author, most recently, of the story collection 'Today a Woman Went Mad in the Supermarket.'. By Evan S. Connell (1969)

title: 'Dalgliesh' Review: Terror in the Nurse's Ward
summary: This latest adaptation of P.D. James's stories sees her titular detective uncovering dark pasts while investigating a poisoning at a medical training facility. No stranger to the impenetrable when it comes to criminal plots, Inspector Adam Dalgliesh (Bertie Carvel) investigates the case of a fatal poisoning at an institution for training nurses in the latest TV saga derived from the novels of P.D. James. (This installment is titled "Shroud for a Nightingale"; two more adaptations, "The Black Tower" and "A Taste for Death," will follow.) The victim is a trainee on whom another student demonstrates the insertion of a feeding tube-a fatal exercise that pumps her full of toxins. Mr. Carvel is the third actor to portray the detective (Roy Marsden who originated the role in the 1980s). The tale, set in mid-1970s England-each installment spans a pair of episodes, two of which roll out on Mondays for three weeks-is never less than gripping in its picture of medical procedures gone wrong, evidently by design. The visual impact-the young trainee reacting to the worst physical anguish imaginable, the chief medical instructor covered in blood-is terrorizing. The atmosphere of dread and depression is pervasive in the drama. We begin to suspect that any tube in a patient's mouth may well not be delivering the medication the doctors had intended-that it just might be transmitting a corrosive substance that kills. What happened to the big container of antiseptic that was in the bathroom?, someone asks. A question now that has special meaning.

title: Companies Call for Clear Climate Policy as They Head to Glasgow
summary: Executives in finance, tech, airlines and other industries call for government frameworks and private money. Senior executives at global companies weigh in on their goals and concerns ahead of the COP26 summit in Glasgow starting next week.

title: I Don't Want a Personal Paradise
summary: A utopian city sounds great at first. Then comes the popularity-and the politics. A story I can't get enough of: Telosa, a mega-billion Xanadu being pitched for the American desert by former Walmart exec and gazillionaire Marc Lore.

title: G-20 Climate Talks Threatened by Clash Over Coal
summary: Climate negotiators worry lack of consensus could cast a shadow over the climate summit in Glasgow. ROME-Leaders from the Group of 20 major economies are split over phasing out coal and limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, officials said, throwing into doubt whether ambitious climate change targets can be hit.

title: Glasgow Expects 25,000 Climate Summit Guests. It Has Just 15,000 Hotel Rooms.
summary: Resume Subscription. A government official from the West African country of Burkina Faso landed in Glasgow last week with an assignment almost as tough as arresting global warming-finding accommodations for 70 during the United Nations climate conference.

title: Hormel Names Smiley Chief Financial Officer as Sheehan Retires
summary: Sheehan, who joined Hormel in 1978, has been chief financial officer since 2016. Hormel Foods Corp. on Friday said Jim Sheehan, executive vice president and chief financial officer, is retiring at the end of the year after four decades with the food maker.

title: Lawmakers Push to Include Medicare Drug-Pricing Provision in Biden Plan
summary: Effort to lower prescription costs was left out of framework on $1.85 trillion social spending and climate proposal. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers pressed forward with efforts to strike a deal enabling Medicare to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies to lower drug costs, despite President Biden's decision to leave the provision out of the framework for a $1.85 trillion social spending and climate package.

title: Former Aide to Gen. MacArthur Took Helm at Oil-Services Company
summary: John P. Laborde, who has died at age 97, ran Tidewater for nearly 40 years and built the largest fleet of vessels serving offshore drillers. When John P. Laborde came home from his Army service in World War II as a junior officer on the staff of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, he was expecting a well-earned rest. Then he found that his oldest brother, C.E. Laborde, had already registered him to resume studies at Louisiana State University. Classes were starting in three days.

title: Pandemic Cigarette-Smoking Boom Appears to Be Over
summary: Altria Group reports accelerating decline in U.S. cigarette sales as people spend more time out and about. After an unusual uptick in sales in the first year of the pandemic, U.S. cigarette purchases are on the decline again as smokers spend more time away from their homes.

title: Stock Market's New EV Joyride Ignores Supply Risks
summary: Investors who are jumping back into electric vehicles should heed the lessons of this year's semiconductor shortages. Investors used to worry about demand for electric vehicles. Supply may turn out to be the real problem.

title: Young Financier Whose Empire Collapsed Found Dead
summary: An investigation is under way and suicide is a possibility, coroner's office in South Carolina says. Alexander Chatfield Burns, a young financier charged with fraud in the wake of a 2014 collapse of his insurance empire, was found dead earlier this week at a residence in Charleston, S.C., the local county coroner's office said.

title: Covid-19 Cases Drop in Southeast Asia, Easing Supply-Chain Crunch
summary: Apple became the latest company to blame disruptions in the region for lost sales. SINGAPORE-Factories have reopened and production is steadily picking up in major manufacturing areas of Southeast Asia as Covid-19 cases have dropped in recent weeks, easing some of the supply-chain constraints that companies blame for lost sales.

title: Apple, Amazon, Lucid, Chevron: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Apple and Amazon shares slip after their earnings reports; Electric-car maker Lucid's shares extend Thursday's gains. Wall Street indexes are slipping after some major earnings reports pointed to risks from supply logjams and difficulty finding workers. Here's what we're watching in Friday's trading:

title: Patagonia Is Boycotting Facebook, Urges Other Companies to Do the Same
summary: Sportswear company wants Facebook to 'prioritize people and planet over profit'. Patagonia is doubling down on its decision to stop all paid advertising on Facebook Inc. platforms, urging other companies to join the sportswear company in its boycott of the social-networking company as it faces widespread scrutiny following the release of internal documents.

title: More Options Emerge to Turn Retirement Savings Into Retirement Paychecks
summary: More money managers, including investment giant BlackRock, are starting to offer annuities inside 401(k) investment options. The retirement paycheck, a staple of the old-fashioned pension plan, is staging a comeback. This time, it is inside the 401(k).

title: Zoom, Slack, Google Hangouts and More: The Hidden Risks of Remote Work
summary: A researcher says they have many benefits. But they also come with four big downsides: isolation, exclusion, surveillance and self-censorship.. Remote-work technologies are great tools-but are they reshaping work relationships in unexpected ways? Lebene Soga thinks so.

title: Why Zoom Fatigue Is Worse Among Women and New Employees
summary: Allowing workers to turn off their cameras could make a big difference, research suggests. Many people are familiar with what is known as Zoom fatigue, described as the feeling of being drained and lacking energy following a day of virtual meetings. Now, new research suggests that women and newer employees may be most susceptible to the phenomenon and that allowing people to turn off their cameras during meetings could make a big difference.

title: Halloween Is Back On This Year: 'We Are Going All Out'
summary: Trick-or-treating, classroom celebrations and town costume parades are making a comeback after Covid-19 concerns forced many festivities to shut down last year. Halloween might actually feel normal again this year. Almost.

title: Why Sesame Street Is More Vital Than Ever
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: How Gary Shteyngart Always Stays at 'Inbox Zero'
summary: The author, 49, most recently of "Our Country Friends: A Novel," shares what's on his phone.. Number of unread emails

title: Exxon, Chevron Amass Cash as Oil Tops $80 a Barrel
summary: Large oil companies are reporting the strongest quarterly revenue since before the start of the pandemic and pulling back on spending. Big oil companies are generating their biggest cash flows in years and heeding investor calls to return it to shareholders instead of using it to drill.

title: 2022 Lucid Air: At Last, a Worthy Tesla Opponent
summary: With industry-leading range and a dual-motor array maxing out at 1,111 hp, the Lucid Air Dream Edition Performance marks the arrival of another serious contender in the electric luxury-sedan market. NOW IT STARTS to get interesting.

title: Mark Zuckerberg's Latest Pivot Is Personal as Well as Strategic
summary: Facebook co-founder's plan to focus on the metaverse is a bold play as he and the company are under more scrutiny than ever. Mark Zuckerberg's announcement that Facebook Inc. is focusing on the metaverse and changing its name to Meta Platforms Inc. is in many ways a personal rebranding as much as a corporate one.

title: The Turnarounds That Sparked Michigan and Michigan State to Undefeated Starts
summary: The No. 6 Wolverines face the No. 8 Spartans in the rivals' first top-10 meeting since 1964. Mike Hart cemented his place in Michigan football lore as a senior running back in 2007-and not because he rushed for 110 yards in a come-from-behind 28-24 win over Michigan State. His legacy came from what he said later about the Spartans.

title: Infrastructure Bill's Broadband Plan Shrouded From Scrutiny
summary: A provision of Congress's $42 billion plan to expand broadband into underserved areas could exempt it from Freedom of Information and Privacy acts. WASHINGTON-Congress is poised to shield a $42 billion broadband grant program from federal transparency and privacy laws, hampering oversight of money expected to flow mostly to telecommunications companies.

title: Eurozone Economy Outpaces U.S., China
summary: Region snapped back strongly in the summer, but supply-chain disruptions now biting into growth. FRANKFURT-The eurozone economy grew briskly in the summer, outpacing the larger U.S. and Chinese economies as the loosening of social restrictions and widespread vaccinations powered the region's comeback from the Covid-19 pandemic, but supply-chain bottlenecks and rising prices are expected to hold growth back in the coming months.

title: Appian Scores Hefty Returns on Brazilian Mine Sales
summary: The mining-focused firm is selling nickel and copper projects in Brazil to strategic buyer Sibanye-Stillwater. Private-equity firm Appian Capital Advisory is poised to generate a 60% internal rate of return from the sale of two Brazilian mining companies, benefiting from rising demand for metals used in electric-vehicle batteries, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: How to Tame China's Wild Pork Price Cycle
summary: African swine fever and Covid-19 have magnified volatility, but further industry consolidation will help. After a rollercoaster-like two years, pork prices in China have come back to earth. Price swings have been magnified by two health crises-African swine fever and Covid-19. But the collateral damage to small farms could actually make for a somewhat less wild price cycle in the future, as the slow consolidation of China's massive pig-rearing industry takes another step forward.

title: U.S. Sanctions Cut Huawei's Revenue for Fourth Straight Quarter
summary: Chinese telecom giant continues to suffer from plunging smartphone sales due to U.S. restrictions on suppliers. HONG KONG-Huawei Technologies Co. said its revenue fell 38% in the most recent quarter, as U.S. restrictions on its access to global chip supplies continued to take a toll on the Chinese company.

title: American Banks Have What They Want in China. Their Fate Is Still Out of Their Hands.
summary: U.S. investment banks and asset managers can finally control their local subsidiaries in China. That spells huge opportunity-but also plenty of pitfalls.. American investors are probably warier of China now than at any time in decades. Relations between the two countries are tense, and the prospect of a wider fallout from the struggles of property giant China Evergrande Group hovers over the market.

title: How Cheesecake Saved the Cheesecake Factory
summary: Resume Subscription. With its massive menu offering everything from crispy chicken sandwiches to coconut cream cakes, Cheesecake Factory Inc. already ran among the most complicated operations in the restaurant industry. It's emerging from the pandemic with a model that's even more sprawling and complex.

title: The Death of a Spouse Is Hard. Taxes Make It Harder.
summary: Beware of shifting tax brackets, retirement-account issues, and missed deadlines that can cost dearly. When Jessica Wyles's husband died suddenly in 2019 at age 57, she found herself facing not only profound grief but also a slew of unfamiliar tax issues.

title: After Alibaba's $400 Billion Stock Selloff, Investors Hope the Worst Is Over
summary: They may have to wait a while for the former market darling to regain its glory. SINGAPORE-Investors are betting the worst is over for Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. after a punishing selloff that halved the market value of the Chinese e-commerce giant in less than a year.

title: Democrats Weigh Tax Cuts for High-Tax States
summary: With tax rates steady and $10,000 deduction cap under attack, some residents of high-tax states might pay less than before 2017. WASHINGTON-High-income coastal professionals look likely to emerge as significant winners from the Democrats' proposed tax agenda, escaping rate increases and regaining a deduction for state and local taxes that was capped at $10,000 in 2017.

title: Facebook's Four New Letters Won't Spell Alphabet
summary: Social network's new Meta identity doesn't compare well with Google's earlier shift. The first in a three-part series on Facebook's finances

title: Evergrande Averts Default Again by Making Second Late Payment
summary: Indebted developer pays $45 million before end of grace period. China Evergrande Group avoided default for a second time by making an overdue interest payment on dollar bonds shortly before the end of a 30-day grace period, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Myanmar Unrest May Be Driving Regional Meth Surge, U.N. Drug Agency Says
summary: Warning comes after authorities in Laos seized a record haul of methamphetamine. SINGAPORE-The United Nations' drug agency warned that political unrest in Myanmar may be driving a surge in production of methamphetamine, as authorities in neighboring Laos carried out Asia's largest known drug-trafficking bust.

title: Global Chip Shortage 'Is Far From Over' as Wait Times Get Longer
summary: Nearly a year into the crisis, some customers are finding it is taking months more than expected to get needed parts. Almost a year into a global chip shortage, the problems are increasing for many customers as delays get even longer and sales are lost.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
